data.title: How was Greece able to successfully repel the Persian invasion under Xerxes I, despite being greatly outnumbered?
data.meta_description:
Answer: The Greeks were fighting in phalanxes, heavy infantry formations. The Persian army had practically no armor (made from wicker) and depended on mobility and especially elite cavalry.

According to military historian Richard Holmes (Oxford Companion to Military History) in the key resulting...
